official-title.#text:
To amend title II of the Social Security Act to implement various reforms to the social security
			 disability insurance program, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Disability Insurance Protection and Fraud Prevention Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Disability Insurance Protection and Fraud Prevention Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text: Expansion of Cooperative Disability Investigations program

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall increase the number of cooperative
			 disability investigative units to 54.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Inspector General of the
			 Social Security Administration

text.#text: Not later than 1 year after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall locate the cooperative disability investigative units established
			 pursuant to

in such manner as to ensure that such units are
			 distributed equally among the most densely populated areas of the Nation.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Disability Insurance Protection and Fraud Prevention Act of 2014/s:2/ss:a

text.#text: The

header.#text: Modification of certain criteria for the determination of disability

text.#text: In determining whether an individual is under a disability for purposes of

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 223 of the
			 Social Security Act

text.#text:
may not consider an individual as approaching advanced age (as applicable for purposes of section
			 404.1563 of title 20, Code of Federal Regulations, as in effect on the
			 date of the enactment of this Act), unless the individual has attained the
			 age of 58;

may not consider an individual as having attained advanced age (as so applicable) unless the
			 individual has attained the age of 61; and

may not consider the individual’s inability to communicate in English as a vocational factor (as
			 applicable for purposes of section 404.1564 of such title).

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Disability Insurance Protection and Fraud Prevention Act of 2014/s:3/ss:a

text.#text: Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

header.#text: Combined effect of impairments not considered in disability determinations

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 223(d)(2) of the Social Security Act

text.#text:
The amendments made by this section shall take effect on the day that is 90 days after the date of
			 enactment of this Act.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Disability Insurance Protection and Fraud Prevention Act of 2014/s:6/ss:b

text.#text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall screen such applicants and target those
			 who appear likely to be determined eligible for benefits but who also have
			 the potential for significant work activity if provided with a range of
			 services to be determined by the

. In exchange for suspending
			 their social security disability insurance program application, these
			 applicants would be offered a package of benefits, including targeted
			 vocational and health interventions, wage subsidies based on how much the
			 applicants can work and earn, and, if appropriate, an emergency cash
			 diversion grant.

text.#text:
In order to improve the well-being of certain social security disability insurance applicants while
			 also achieving near-term program cost neutrality and long-term cost
			 savings, the

header.#text: State disability reform demonstration program report

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
a report describing the design of a demonstration
			 program that would meet the specifications in

, including
			 recommendations for any legislative changes necessary to implement such a
			 program.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Disability Insurance Protection and Fraud Prevention Act of 2014/s:7/ss:b

text.#text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall work with the States to determine whether, if appropriate
			 changes were made in the law, the existing funding streams for specific
			 populations, such as vocational rehabilitation funding, Medicaid,
			 Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, and workers’ compensation, could
			 be modified to be delivered in a more coordinated manner to improve
			 outcomes and reduce participation in supplemental security income or
			 social security disability insurance.

text.#text: The

States who successfully implemented such a program shall receive incentive funding to be determined
			 by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
as likely to receive a
			 lifetime of supplemental security income or social security disability
			 insurance.

text.#text: For the purposes of this section, the term

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
a report describing the design of a demonstration
			 program that would meet the specifications in

, including
			 recommendations for any legislative changes necessary to implement such a
			 program.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Disability Insurance Protection and Fraud Prevention Act of 2014/s:8/ss:b

text.#text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall create a voluntary
			 program for employers that would provide such employers with a tax credit
			 with respect to social security disability insurance taxes if the
			 employees of such employer do not file for social security disability
			 insurance.

text.#text:
In order to encourage employers to reduce the incidence of disability among their employees by 20
			 percent, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall determine a baseline predicted rate of social security disability
			 insurance enrollment.

text.#text: For each employer who volunteers to participate in the program, the

Employees employed on the date the employer enrolled in the program shall be tracked for a period
			 of 3 years beginning on the date of enrollment in the program, whether or
			 not they remain employed by such employer. If any such employee becomes
			 eligible for social security disability insurance during such period, the
			 employer’s disability insurance participation rate shall be affected.

At the end of the period, the employer’s disability insurance participation rate shall be compared
			 to the baseline, and if the participation rate has fallen by at least 20
			 percent, the employer shall receive a social security disability insurance
			 tax credit of 75 percent of the disability insurance cost savings during
			 the period.
